content:
The difference between the first day of the first and last years ofmiddle school is immense. The start of your first year is the mostimportant day in your life, and the start of the last year is the mostunimportant.

Joseph Warren had long since been through his first year of middleschool and was advising his younger sister, Rosie, on how to geteverything she could out of the first day of school, while theylounged on their living room couch.

"The last thing you want to do is glue yourself to the people youknew in elementary school. The world is bigger than that now."

Joe spoke with the authority of a professor that was giving a lectureon the most important branch of the physical sciences. An impressionthat Rosie upheld with the rigid dedication of a Harvard student.

Rosie politely raised her hand, "How do you reccomend meeting thesenew people?"

"Mostly through your classes," Joe answered, "I'd also advise onjoining at least one club. I never did that, but everyone else tellsme that they made their best friends in some-club-or-other."

Rosie nodded in contemplation, carefully considering what her olderbrother said.

Joe carried on with his lesson, "Something that I undervalued backwhen I was starting out was showing up to classes. I didn't think itwould be that hard to do—"

Rosie's eyes widened, "You cut classes?"

Joe immediently backpedaled, "Oh no no no no! I could never! Butdespite my pleading, all of my former friends succumbed to thedisease."

Rosie giggled, "You're trying to make yourself sound smart again…"

Joe rolled his eyes, "It's to convey the importance of the things Ilearned by attending school, Rosie, I wanna make sure you stay ontrack to kick this school's ass both physically and timemanagement…ly."

"Nice one, bro"

"Oh, shut up. I was trying to tell you that you shouldn't cutclass!"

Rosie rolled her eyes, all traces of a mock-professor/student dynamichaving faded into the mundanity of sibling dynamics.

"Anyways," Joe continued, "don't be an asshole to people you don'tknow. It gets more blurry with your friends, but I'd reccomend notsaying anything too mean to them as well."

"Joe, that is the most self-obvious piece of advice I've everheard," Rosie said, "is the next nugget gonna be "don't murder yourteachers" or something like that."

Joe snorted, "Oh yeah, little miss swiping at my back when I'mpicking up my sword, you can be ruthless sometimes."h"Only to people who deserve to know that what they said was asinineas hell," Rosie said, "and I apologized for the backstab already,Jesus Christ Joe."

Joe grinned, "Relax Rosie, I'm kidding."

There was a long pause as a look of worry knit itself across Rosie'sface.

Rosie sighed and finally spoke up, "Hey Joe?"

"Yeah?"

She paused for a moment before continuing, "Should I try to givemyself a new nickname? Rosie just feels so childish and youngsounding."

"Uh," Joe leaned back further into the couch's pile of pillows andblankets as if he could escape his uncertainty, "I don't know. Ikind of know where you're coming from, if that helps at all. Joeisn't exactly the coolest name in the book, and Joey and Joseph aren'ta whole lot better."

She ran her fingers through her hair distractedly, "Does it reallymatter what my nickname is? Am I over-thinking it?"

From the pillows, Joe said, "I don't think it matters a whole lot,honestly. I guess as long as you stay true to who you are andwhatever. Names have power, but as long as the label you stick onyourself doesn't subsume your very "

"Joe?"

"Yeah?"

"That was the most incoherent self-indulgy monologue I've heard in along time. Have you been thinking a lot about this?"

"No," Joe started, "maybe. I said it before, Joe is a bit of a lamename. It gives the impression of a middle age football coach whopeaked in high-school."

"You're young, there's still time for that"

Joe got out of the cushions and half heartedly swiped at his sister.

"Shut up."

"Never," she said, "anyways. What about Rose?"

"Huh? Oh right."

Joe thought for a few moments before nodding his head in approval.

"I like Rose, it feels clever."

Rose beamed and said, "Like me!"

Joe ignored the comment, "Do you think I should take on a nicknametoo? I know its really too late to, but I've got a strange feelingthat I ought to, you know?"

Rose considered her words carefully before speaking again, "I thinkthat's a personal question, Joe. Besides, its not really too late.You can always adopt a screenname, seperate from your own to useonline."

Joe sighed and ran his hand through his hair.

"Yeah you're right," Joe said, "I'll leave it be for the year, andif I come up with an ingenious idea that'll blow everyone's minds withhow cool it is I'll use it next year."

Rose punched Joe's shoulder, and said, "That's the spirit. Justdon't forget your advice. What was it? Don't let the nickname becomea mask that become all that you are or whatever that means."

"Oh shut up, Rosie."

content:
Joe entered his history classroom the next day exhausted from a busyday of learning the conflicting expectations that his teachers wouldbe piling onto him for the remainder of the year. As he entered theroom, he didn't expect anything less than more of the same.

Just one more class of the same people talking about the same thingsfor an hour.

He spotted one of his friends and plopped himself down in the adjacentdesk, safe in the knowledge that he'd at least have one person in thisclass he could talk to.

"Hiya, Jess."

Jessica Yamagawa waved to Joe without taking her head off the desk she was laying on.

"How's your day been, Jess?"

"Blegh," Jess said, "I've gotten all of the bad teachers. All of them!"

Joe rolled his eyes, "I doubt you have all of the bad teachers considering you can only have six teachers at a time, and you haven't even met the last one yet."

Jess picked her head up off the desk and glared at Joe, her dark brown hair still plastered to the side of her face.

"Fine then, jackass. I haven't gotten all the bad teachers, but I'd sure say that all of the ones I've had today are bad."

"Whoemst've?"

Jess sighed and brushed her hair back behind her ear. After that, she reached into her open backpack and pulled out her schedule.

"Bio, Max Roberts; English, Lillian Bonner; PE, James Hernando; Spanish, Rosalina Fernandez; and Algebra 2, Olivia Denton," she read off the list monotonically, without a shred of intrest in her voice..

"Why are they the worst then? Your tone and face reflect more apathy than antipathy."

"Roberts, Hernando, and Fernandez are dull and lifeless," Jess said without pause as she counted the names off on her fingers, "Denton can't be bothered to answer questions about our syllabus, which leaves me little confidence that she won't just let us loose on polynomials with little more than a prayer to help us with them," Jess took a breath, "and finally and worstly, I've heard that Bonner doesn't look on people like me with kind eyes. It's just a rumor, but one I'm not thrilled about figuring out the truth behind."

Joe looked visibly distressed at the final statement, "Jesus Jess. Is there anything I can do?"

Jess sighed, "I doubt it. If it turns out that she's a shit person I'll record it and file a complaint with the school, either they deal with the problem or transfer me to a different class to shut me up. So I'll be fine."

"I," Joe held a conflicted expression on his face, "trust you. And I trust you to know what to do and how to do it. So I'll drop it for now. But if it does come to that or anything else, please let me know, okay?"

Jess grinned slightly, "Thanks Joe, I appreciate it. Don't worry too much though. More than likely she'll either be a tolerable annoyance, or the rumors will just be the standard level of true rumors are."

The two sat in silence for a few moments. Joe took the opportunity to get his supplies for class out.

He placed his notebook, mechanical pencil, erasers, and pen onto his desk as neatly and deliberately as he could manage. Everything was to be placed in a coherent manner that allowed for easy access.

Joe looked around the room in order to figure out who he would be dealing with the rest of the year for sixth period. It was all the standard people he had been acquainted with for two years now.

Actually, there was a new person he hadn't seen before.

Joe knew he didn't know every single person his grade level in the school, but he had never seen this girl's face before in the two years he had been at the school.

"Jess."

No response.

"Hey, Jess," Joe repeated, this time with a poke accompanying the vocalization.

"What?"

"Do you see the girl in the corner? The one with the longer blonde hair that isn't done up? She's reading a book right now."

"Yeah? What about her?"

"Do you know who she is?"

"Fuck if I know, Joe," Jess squinted, "oh wait, she has math with me… her name's Robyn Something."

"Strange last name."

"Oh fuck off," Jess replied to the jab with little irritation, "I'm not like you, I don't spend my class staring at dorks. Anyways, why'd you ask?"

"I haven't seen her before," Joe replied susinctly, "I was wondering if she's new."

"Ah yes, classic Joe," Jess drily noted, "I don't recognize this person, they must be from somewhere else!"

"Hey!"

"I'm teasing you, relax dude."

They were both smiling now, lightly ribbing each other in a dance of friendship.

This dance was interrupted by their teacher walking in. The teacher began introducing herself and in doing so had consequently begun the mundanity and boredom in Joe's mind.

Every now and then though, he snuck glances at the new girl, Robyn.

She had an energy about her, one that gave off the impression of disinterest in what outsiders thought of her, of subtle confidence, of being "too cool for school."

The way she carried herself, the way she moved her hair, the way she smirked when she pushed up her aviator shaped glasses, all of it contributed to an undeniable mystique.

And before he knew it, Jess was tapping his shoulder and the day was done.

content:
The night was cold, dark, and a perfectly inopertune time to commence a duel with your little sister.

But thirteen year olds are not known for their wisdom and sound judgment, so Rose and Joe were several floors above ground level with the wind whipping around their heads fast enough for their hair to defy gravity.

Rose had just climbed the ladder onto the rooftop in a sour mood and carried with her both the note that summoned her, and the items requested in said note.

The items which she immediately threw down in between herself and her brother.

"Hiya, Rosie."

She hasn't seen her brother in an entire day, and the minor frustration of the childish nickname she had resolved to outgrow the day before wasn't one she could take right now.

"Rose."

Joe smiled and rephrased himself.

"Hiya, Rose. How was your first day of middle school?"

Ironically Rose was considerably more nervous after having been through the first day of middle school than she was the evening before when her brother was hyping up the experience.

"Horrible," Rose said, "I blew my opportunity to make new friends."

Joe frowned, "Shit sis, I'm sorry about that. Do you want to talk about it?"

"Not yet," Rose gestured down at the twin wooden swords she had brought up, "I need to burn of this energy first."

Joe nodded and moved for his sword, an old fashioned Japanese training sword he picked up years ago when he visited the city.

Rose moved in parallel, grabbing a the European styled sword she had used in these duels since she got it at a fair when she was around 8 years old.

The combatants, now properly equipped, faced each other to commence their esoteric distressing ritual that their parents only barely approved of.

"Ready?"

Rose nodded curtly and went for the first strike.

She took two quick steps forward and swung her sword directly at hey brothers shoulder. Joe returned by slipping through the strike and repositioned himself behind her.

Turning the momentum of the failed attack into a quick spin, Rose blocked Joe's over the head slash with her wooden blade. In their little game, she was at an advantage due to her smaller size, the only two rules they had were to avoid the head and to steer clear of actual injury that would cause their parents to ask questions about what exactly they did when they went out together.

Rose's block wasn't enough to stall the strike, merely slow it, so she was forced to dance closer to the railing on the edge of the roof. The wind was fiercer here, cold and damp.

The two traded blows that they knew the other would be able to avoid or counter back and forth for minutes before Joe, sensing a sluggishness coming into Rose executed the final blow of the game.

He pivoted his feet and swung wide, reversing the blow halfway through and striking the hilt of Rose's blade from below.

The sword leapt from the girl's hand and arced upward, clattering to the ground moments later with a deafening clack… and then silence.

Joe and Rose slowly let their breathing return to normal as the wind cooled them off and dried the sweat on their body.

Joe restarted the conversation from earlier, "would you like to talk now?"

Rose's labored breathing approximated a sigh, "not really, but you're incessant curiosity will ask again later, so I might as well."

Rose took a deep breath, "all the new people probably think I'm weird now. I completely blew my chances for normal friends by saying all the wrong things. I don't know what to do now."

Joe furrowed his brow, "what did you say?"

"One of the boys in my class was talking about looking forward to writing in our English class. So I ask him about him writing. If he liked it."

She was starting to talk quicker now.

"So he says that he writes as a hobby. I say, oh cool and ask whether he'd want to be a writer when he grows."

Her voice was beginning to loose coherence and devolve into sniffles.

"Rose."

"He says yes so I ask about his favorite books, and he says he loves the Hobbit and what not. So I tell him that fantasy has a bunch of sociological ramifications…"

"Rose!"

"And then. And then I ask if he's interested in the Psychology of…"

"ROSIE!"

Rose stopped.

"I asked too many questions, didn't I? I blew my chances didn't I?"

Joe walked over to his sister and hugged her tightly.

"Rose, I… I don't think you did honestly. Why do you think you blew the opportunity to make new friends?"

Rose sounded as if she was crying, but Joe didn't want to break the hug to find out, "He started laughing and I ran. They all think I'm a loser now, I know it."

Joe broke the hug to look into Rose's eyes, "Rose, I wasn't there and can't say for certain, but I bet if you went back tomorrow and apologized to him for whatever you think you did, I bet he would forgive you."

"How do you know that?"

Joe put on his best big brother reassuring smile, "I think people are mostly good. Besides, let's say he views you as weird for asking about things he's not prepared for, do you really want to be friends with someone like that."

"But…"

"Rose, trust me. It's better to have one friend you can be yourself with than a hundred friends you have to pretend to be someone else for. I promise."

Rose was visibly calming down, but Joe didn't know how much of that was her feeling better and how much was her pretending to feel better so he would stop worrying about her.

"Hey, Rose?"

"Yeah?"

"Let's go downstairs, okay? I think finishing this conversation inside would be best for both of us."

Rose unenthusiastically nodded and moved to grab her things. She didn't look great, but she looked better than she had moments before when she was crying.

And that," Joe reasoned, was enough for the moment."
